want to wrap up a little bit my section by talking about some of the things that we've learned as we've designed and
scaled out this network to the 10 gigabit level the first one which sounds probably a little bit obvious to most of
you is you really have to find and eliminate the bottlenecks that arise or
there are designed into your network and and some of these are again sort of
obvious like you know you don't have a gigabit network segment in your 10 gigabit network path but some of them
are a little bit less obvious so for example if you're going to be doing bulk data transfers you need to have a disk
system that is able to do if you want to transfer data out at 10 gigabits per second you have to have a disk system
that's able to deliver data at mega bits per second or at least a gigabyte per second and we were able to
do this pretty reasonably with the the modest sized raid array but for example
when you're doing your testing don't do your testing from your boot volume which is usually not scaled that way another
thing is be careful with your firewall so if you if you put a firewall into your network design and it has 10
gigabit interfaces on it that doesn't necessarily mean that you can drive a single stream 10 gigs all the way
through that firewall firewalls are designed mostly to handle lots of small streams rather than one gigantic stream
we were able to actually drive a large stream through our firewall but it took a lot of tuning and testing with our
security team operations team and with the developers of the firewall itself and the last interesting bottleneck that
I did not expect until we ran up against it was was actually inside of ec2 VPC
itself so you might think that if you've purchased a 10 gigabit direct connect
connection and you have a 10 gigabit capable ec2 interface like a you know
c-38 extra large is one of our common that you'd be able to flow 10 gigs between those two but that's actually
not the case there are internal limit limits within the VPC structure that
we're inside of a VPC instance to instance you can you can go at basically
that the speed that the instance interface is but if you're leaving that VPC if you're either going enter AZ well
actually it's not leaving VPC apologize if you're going into AZ or if you're going out of the VPC out your direct
connect there are smaller limits so so we were able to do about one or two gigabits per second on a per instance
basis from that instance through our direct connect another major lesson
learned something that we've been warned about and we saw firsthand is that packet loss combined with with with the
types of latency that you typically see when you're going you know across the country really combined together to
drastically lower your performance so the folks at es net
help design high-performance networks did a test where they they added packet
loss into a network segment that was as small as 1 in 20,000 packets being dropped and that combined with latency
in the dozens of milliseconds range dropped their observed performance from about six or eight gigabits down to 100
few hundred megabits so this was a 17 X drop so you can see pretty drastic
performance if you have even just small amounts of packet loss so it's really important to design your network to
basically not drop a packet unless there's an emergency situation and the
other thing that we noticed is to try and mitigate some some of those effects as well as effects that were caused by
firewall issues and other things is we really leveraged hard that the technique
of doing parallel stream transfers for both bulk data transfers now there are
lots of technologies out there that will do parallel streams we've settled on the use of Globus grid ftp for doing server
to server transfers and that tends to do a pretty decent job but when we're going
to s3 most of the native s3 tools don't support all of the features that we need
in order to get the highest bandwidth possible meaning multi-part parallel upload download parallel files with kms
encryption and so we actually had to write our own tool in Java using the the
AWS Java API to be able to get the the best possible performance out of doing
an s3 transfer the last thing that we discovered was that um and again we were
sort of a little warned about this was that it's not enough to just design your network and and and and put it forward
and and say oh that's great it's working and walk away you have to continuously
monitor that network that might be a little bit obvious but you also have to continuously test the network to ensure
